title: Kurixalus naso
text:
Kurixalus naso, also known as uphill tree frog, long-snouted treefrog, and Annandale's high altitude frog, is a species of <a href="frog">frog</a> in the family <a href="Rhacophoridae">Rhacophoridae</a>. It is found in northeastern <a href="India">India</a>, southern <a href="Tibet">Tibet</a>, and <a href="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>. A related but unnamed species is found in <a href="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> and <a href="Yunnan">Yunnan</a> (China). Furthermore, it is possible that "<a href="Kurixalus%20yangi">Kurixalus yangi</a>" (Yunnan, Myanmar, and NE India) is a <a href="Synonym%20%28taxonomy%29">junior synonym</a> of "Kurixalus naso".
Description.
"Kurixalus naso" is a small frog, growing to about in <a href="snout%E2%80%93vent%20length">snout–vent length</a>; Yu and colleagues report lengths up to for males. The snout is noticeably pointed. The limbs have serrated dermal fringes. The chin and breast are granular. Dorsal coloration is generally brownish, mixed with dark markings. The ventral surface is shaded posteriorly with dark spots. The <a href="Iris%20%28anatomy%29">iris</a> is golden. Males have a single, internal <a href="vocal%20sac">vocal sac</a>.
Habitat and conservation.
"Kurixalus naso" is an <a href="arboreal">arboreal</a> species occurring in tropical forest, shrubland and grasslands at elevations of <a href="above%20sea%20level">above sea level</a>. Breeding takes place in small, temporary water pools.
The overall population of "Kurixalus naso" is believed to be small. It is threatened by <a href="deforestation">deforestation</a>. It is present in two protected areas in northeastern India, <a href="Dihang-Dibang%20Biosphere%20Reserve">Dihang-Dibang Biosphere Reserve</a> and <a href="Mouling%20National%20Park">Mouling National Park</a>.
